Thanks Karl,
for the answers. But can you shortly discribe what does mean energy 
on/off, and what influence does have multi component transport on the 
solution in comparission to non multi transport. 
How I explained in the first message I would like to calculate 
flamespeeds for n-heptane/air mixtures, what would be the best method 
to use. Can you write some lines of code in Phyton to explain. I guess 
there are many people who are interested in this ass well. Hopefully 
we dont need Chemkin anymore :-)
Thank you very much in advance

Sven

p.s. I suppose you have develeped the freely propagating module, many 
thanks for that.


--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Karl Meredith" <kvm@c...> wrote:
> 
> Sven,
> 
> Mdot is used as an initial guess for the flowfield.  The actual mdot 
is part
> of the solution.  Once the initial temperature guess has been 
specified, the
> user needs to choose a temperature at a location to hold constant.  
This is
> done by:
> 
> 	flame.setFixedTemperature(900.0);
> 
> Then the user needs to specify that this flame is adiabatic
> 
> 	flame.setAdiabaticFlame();
> 
> Once this is done then the solution can be obtained by running:
> 
> 	flame.solve(loglevel=1,refine_grid);
> 
> Karl
> 
> 
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: cantera@yahoogroups.com [mailto:cantera@yahoogroups.com]On 
Behalf
> Of cantera_user
> Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 11:25 AM
> To: cantera@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [cantera] question about freely propagating flame in phyton
> 
> 
> Hello guys,
> can anyone give a brief description on how the new freely 
propagating
> flame tools works, please? In the beginning you have to choose mdot 
e.
> g. but it is not used in the further routines anymore. Can anyone
> please explain shortly how it works, and what would be the best 
method
> to use. I would really like to calculate some flame speeds for n-
> heptane.
> Thanks in advance for an answer
> 
> Sven
>
